<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 288, 178, 304]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 288, 905, 304]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 405, 328]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 312, 905, 328]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 222, 446]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 808, 570]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 213, 614]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 615, 730, 648]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 918, 117]]<|/det|>
A spring is attached to a strong cylindrical magnet of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\). The magnet is placed on thin card on top of a magnetic sheet on the bench, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 123, 767, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 348, 532, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 895, 397]]<|/det|>
The thickness of the card is \(t\). The magnetic flux density at one of the poles of the magnet is \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 410, 918, 444]]<|/det|>
A force is applied upwards to the spring. The extension of the spring when the magnet just leaves the card is \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 457, 559, 475]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(s\) is related to \(t\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 485, 549, 514]]<|/det|>
\[ks = \frac{ALBZ}{t}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 640, 541]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is the spring constant of the spring and \(Z\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 553, 687, 571]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(s\) and \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 625, 603]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 653, 634]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine a value for \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 647, 383, 664]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 395, 693]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 705, 410, 723]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 735, 348, 752]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 351, 782]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 794, 447, 811]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resonant frequency of a metal rod. The metal rod of length \(L\) is suspended from two rubber loops. A sensitive microphone with a cone is positioned at one end of the rod. The microphone is attached to an oscilloscope, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 141, 888, 331]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 343, 591, 361]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 415, 392]]<|/det|>
The rod is hit gently with a hammer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 690, 424]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of the trace produced on the oscilloscope is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 546, 455]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 571, 485]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(T\) and \(L\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 496, 536, 524]]<|/det|>
\[T = \frac{2L^n}{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 364, 551]]<|/det|>
where C and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 146, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 680, 583]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\lg T\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\lg L\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 611, 613]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 764, 917, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 796, 917, 815]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 813, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 148, 100]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 81, 489, 100]]<|/det|> Values of \(L\) and \(T\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 114, 541, 131]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 144, 875, 463]]<|/det|>
\(L/\mathrm {cm}\)\(T/10^{-5}s\)\(\lg (L/\mathrm {cm})\)\(\lg (T/10^{-5}s)\)
54\(24\pm 1\)
70\(32\pm 1\)
86\(39\pm 1\)
108\(49\pm 2\)
140\(64\pm 2\)
167\(74\pm 2\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 732, 491]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\lg (L / \mathrm{cm})\) and \(\lg (T / 10^{- 5} \text{s})\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 486, 470, 505]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\lg T\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 918, 505]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 518, 144, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 180, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 518, 787, 537]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\lg (T / 10^{- 5} \text{s})\) against \(\lg (L / \mathrm{cm})\). Include error bars for \(\lg T\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 918, 537]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 180, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 549, 920, 584]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 565, 920, 584]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 596, 180, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 596, 920, 630]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 816, 920, 834]]<|/det|>
gradient = ....................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 816, 920, 834]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 83, 180, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 81, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 268, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 148, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 300, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(n\) and \(C\). Include the absolute uncertainties in your values. You need not be concerned with units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>C = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 657, 146, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 656, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the length \(L\) of the rod that gives a value of \(T\) of \(0.10 \text{ms}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 841, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 874, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 915, 920, 952]]<|/det|>
